{{Infobox religious biography |name = Yongming Yanshou
{{linktext|永|明|延|壽}} |image=Yongming_Yanshou_Image.jpg |caption = |birth name = |alias = |dharma name = |birth_date = 904 |birth_place = [[Hangzhou]] or [[Yuhang District|Yuhang]] |death_date = 975 (aged 72) |death_place = |nationality = |religion = [[Buddhism]] |school = [[Zen|Chán]] |lineage = |title = [[Zen Master|Chán master]] |location = |education = |occupation = |teacher = [[Tiantai Deshao]] |reincarnation of = |predecessor = [[Tiantai Deshao]] |successor = |students = |spouse = |partner = |children = |website = }} {{ZenBuddhism}} '''Yongming Yanshou''' ({{zh|t=永明延壽|p=|w=Yung-ming Yen-shou}}; {{CJKV|k=Yǒngmyǒng Yǒnsu|j=永明延寿 or Yōmyō Enju|v=Vĩnh Minh Diên Thọ}}) (904–975) was a prominent [[Buddhist]] monk during the [[Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period]] and early [[Song Dynasty]] in [[China]]. ==Biography== Yongming Yanshou is first mentioned in biographical form by Zanning (贊寧) in a work called the ''Song Biographies of Eminent Monks'' ({{zh|t=宋高僧傳|p=song gaoseng zhuan}}), which was produced in 988, 12 years after Yanshou's death.{{citation|last=Welter|first=Albert|title=Yongming Yanshou's Conception of Chan in the Zongjing Lu: A Special Transmission Within the Scriptures|year=2011|isbn=978-0-19-976031-2|publisher=Oxford University Press}}{{citation|last=Welter|first=Albert|title=The Meaning of Myriad Good Deeds: A Study of Yung-ming Yen-shou and the Wan-shan t'ung-kuei chi|year=1992|isbn=978-0-8204-1796-7|publisher=P. Lang}} Yanshou lived largely during the [[Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period]], in the independent [[Wuyue|Wuyue kingdom]]. This age was characterized by nearly continuous warfare and political disorder. The future of Buddhism was especially uncertain during this time due to widespread [[Four Buddhist Persecutions in China|suppression and sponsored destruction of temples]]. However, most of this activity took place in the north of China, while Yanshou resided in the independent [[Wuyue|Wuyue kingdom]] of the south, which was relatively stable during this time. Furthermore, unlike the trouble Buddhism faced in the north, the ruling [[Qian (surname)|Qian]] family heavily patronized Buddhist and other religious institutions. He was born in either the capital city of Wuyue, modern-day [[Hangzhou]], or a suburb of it, [[Yuhang District|Yuhang]], in the year 904. He would have served as an official before becoming a monk, although the exact nature of the position is disagreed upon in biographical sources. He probably became a monk around 932 under the [[Zen]] teacher Ts'ui Yen. At some point he left his initial teacher and went to [[Tiantai Mountain|Mount Tiantai]], where his attainment was confirmed by the teacher Tiantai Dehshao. Around 952 he again moved, this time to Mount Xuědòu (雪窦山), where he served as a teacher and apparently attracted many students. He is said to have practiced [[Buddhist chant|seated chanting]] and [[Zazen|silent meditation]]. In 960, the King of Wuyue, [[Qian Chu]], assigned Yanshou to be the abbot of [[Lingyin Temple]], which the king had recently re-established. Only a year later in 961, the king relocated Yanshou to the newly constructed [[Jingci Temple|Yongming Temple]], from which he would take his name. Here Yanshou is said to have become very prominent. He received gifts from the King of Korea, [[Gwangjong of Goryeo]], and in return he ordained 36 Korean monks, who then returned home to teach. In 974 he returned to Mount Tiantai, and the following year he died. ==Teachings and influence== Yongming Yanshou is best known for attempting to synthesize the diverse and seemingly contradictory teachings of the various schools of Buddhism that existed in China. He is often associated with [[Pure Land Buddhism]] and [[Zen]], but Pure Land largely formed after his lifetime, and he is largely concerned with [[Hua Yan]] in his writings, equating Hua Yan as when the teachings on the One Mind relies on doctrine (Yi Jiao) and these teachings are in the form of Chan when this Mind is directly revealed.Zongmi on Chan Because he held views that conflicted with the [[Rinzai]] tradition, which came to be the dominant school of [[Japanese Zen]], he has been criticized or marginalized in many later accounts of Zen history. As a result of this, he was largely ignored by Western scholars of Chan in the 20th century, most of whom worked from a Japanese perspective. Nonetheless, recent Western scholarship recognizes his importance, and he has been an enduring influential figure in the eyes of [[Chinese Chán|Chinese]], Korean, and Vietnamese branches of Zen, and he is deeply revered in the Pure Land school.{{Citation | publisher = Oxford University Press | isbn = 978-0-19-536764-5 | editor1 = Steven Heine | editor2 = Dale Wright | title = Zen Masters | year = 2010 | last=Welter | first=Albert |contribution=Yongming Yanshou: Scholastic as Chan Master | pages = 59–89 }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * Benn, James A (2007), Burning for the Buddha, University of Hawaii Press, pp. 104-131. {{ISBN|0824823710}} * Wu, Zhongwei (2007), [https://www.jstor.org/stable/27823298 The mind as the essence of words: A linguistic philosophical analysis of the classification teaching of Yongming Yanshou]. Frontiers of Philosophy in China 2 (3), 336-344{{Subscription required |via=[[JSTOR]]}} {{Zen}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yanshou, Yongming}} [[Category:Zen]] [[Category:904 births]] [[Category:976 deaths]] [[Category:Song dynasty Buddhists]] [[Category:Wuyue Buddhist monks]] [[Category:10th-century Chinese people]] [[Category:Buddhism in China]] [[Category:Chinese Buddhist monks]] [[Category:Chinese Zen Buddhists]] [[Category:History of Buddhism]]

{{expert-subject|psychology|talk=Neutrality|date=January 2015}}
'''Zou huo ru mo''' ({{zh|c=走火入魔 |p=zǒuhuǒrùmó}}) or {{clarify |text='''qigong deviation''' ({{zh|t=氣功偏差 |p=qìgōngpiānchā |l=qigong deviation/error}} or {{zh|s=气功出偏}}),|reason=In 氣功偏差 and 气功出偏, the first two characters mean qigong, even though they look a little different because the first term is in traditional Chinese characters and the second term is in simplified Chinese characters. However, the second two characters in each term mean different things. So both of these terms might be correct and they might even have the same romanization, but references along with quotes for evidence are necessary to figure out which or both of these terms should be used here and in the Backround section. See also the clarify reason in the Background section. |date=February 2018}} is a [[Chinese-culture]] concept traditionally used to indicate that something has gone wrong in [[Chinese spiritual world concepts|spiritual]] or [[Chinese martial arts|martial arts]] training. The qigong community uses this term to describe a physiological or [[psychological disorder]] believed to result during or after [[qigong]] practice, due to "improper practice" of qigong and other self-cultivation techniques. The concept was highlighted in the social and political context of [[Qigong fever|mass popularization of qigong in China]].
==Background==
The Chinese word ''zǒuhuǒrùmó'' ({{zh|c=走火入魔}} "①be obsessed with sth. ②possessed by the Devil") combines ''zǒuhuǒ(r)'' ("①〈elec.〉 ⓐspark ⓑhave a short circuit ②〈coll.〉 discharge (a firearm) accidentally ③overstate ④catch fire; be on fire") and ''rùmó'' ("①be spellbound ②be infatuated/obsessed").<ref>Translation equivalents from [[Wenlin]], Version 4.2.2, 2015.</ref> In recent times this syndrome has been known as {{clarify|text=''qìgōngpiānchā'' ({{zh|t=氣功偏差}} "qigong deviation/error").|reason=This second term is different than the second term used in the intro originally. Copied this term to the intro and also requested clarification there. |date=February 2018}}{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} The term has traditionally been applied to indicate that something has gone wrong in one's martial arts training, interpreted as "imbalance of qi (life energy)".
In more recent history, the term has been applied to refer to undesirable somatic or psychological effects experienced during or after the practice of the broad range of Chinese self-cultivation exercises known as [[qigong]].<ref name=Nancy3 /><ref name=Shan/> Most cases do not last for an extended period of time, and are never brought to medical attention.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lee|first=Sing|title=Cultures in psychiatric nosology: the CCMD-2-R and international classification of mental disorders|journal=Cult Medicine Psychiatry|date=December 1996|volume=20|issue=4|pages=421–472|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF00117087|accessdate=2013-05-14|doi=10.1007/bf00117087}}</ref>
While qigong could potentially act as a stressor in some vulnerable individuals, relations between qigong and disorders are manifold, and causal relationships have not been demonstrated.<ref name=Ng1998>Ng BY. 1998. "Qigong-induced mental disorders: a review." ''[[Australian & New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry]]'' 33(2):197-206.</ref> Similar syndromes have been observed in other forms of self-cultivation practices such as [[yoga]] ([[Kundalini syndrome]]),<ref>{{cite book | last= Upadhyaya |first= Pt.Rajnikant | year=2006|date= |title= Awake Kundalini | publisher= Lotus Press | isbn=81-8382-039-5 | pages = 26}}</ref> [[meditation]],<ref>{{cite book | last= Nelson |first= James M. | year=2009 |date= |title= Psychology, Religion, and Spirituality | publisher= Springer | isbn=0-387-87572-7 | pages = 470}}</ref> and [[hypnosis]].<ref>{{cite book | last= Gibson |first= Hamilton Bertie | year=1991 |date= |title= Hypnosis in therapy | publisher= [[Psychology Press]] | isbn=0-86377-155-6 | pages = }}</ref>
==Symptoms==
Symptoms are often identified as being in one of three categories: # panic, discomfort, and uncontrolled spontaneous movement; # sensory problems, such as visual or auditory hallucination; and # irrational beliefs.<ref name=Nancy3 >{{cite book|last= Chen |first=Nancy N. | year=2003|date= |title= Breathing spaces: qigong, psychiatry, and healing in China |publisher= [[Columbia University Press]] |isbn=0-231-12804-5 | chapter=Chapter 4. Qiqong Deviation or Psychosis | pages = 77–107| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Q5-Gk8jBCUUC&lpg=PP1&dq=Breathing%20spaces%3A%20qigong%2C%20psychiatry%2C%20and%20healing%20in%20China.%20Columbia%20University%20Press&pg=PA77#v=onepageq=Breathing%20spaces:%20qigong,%20psychiatry,%20and%20healing%20in%20China.%20Columbia%20University%20Press&f=false}}</ref>
Somatic symptoms can include sensations and pain in head, chest and back, abdomen, limbs, or whole body; whereas, mental and emotional symptoms can include [[neurasthenia]], [[affective disorder]], [[self-consciousness]], [[hallucination]], and [[paranoia]].<ref name=Liu2013CMQ />{{rp|165–167}}
==Diagnosis== While the Chinese Society of Psychiatry prefers the term "qigong deviation", the American Psychiatric Association uses psychosis terminology.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Liu | first1 = Lydia He | title = Tokens of exchange: the problem of translation in global circulations | year = 1999 | publisher = [[Duke University Press]] | location = [[Durham, North Carolina]] | isbn = 978-0-8223-2424-9 | pages =315 | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=TItoIpT8hFcC&pg=PA315 }}</ref> Some physicians believe that this disease can be categorized as a [[culture-bound syndrome]], but this point is debated.<ref name=Shan>{{cite journal|last=Shan|first=HH|title=Culture-bound psychiatric disorders associated with qigong practice in China|journal=Hong Kong J Psychiatry|year=2000|pages=10–14|url=http://easap.asia/journal_file/0004_Culture_bound%2012_14.pdf}}</ref>
===Chinese psychiatry=== In the second edition of the [[Chinese Classification of Mental Disorders]] (CCMD-2) published by the [[Chinese Society of Psychiatry]]<ref>{{Cite journal | last = The Chinese Society of Psychiatry | title = 66. Qigong deviation syndrome | journal = Chinese Classification and diagnostic criteria of mental disorders (CCMD-2) | volume = CCMD-2 | location = Beijing | year = 1989 }}</ref> the diagnosis of “Qigong Deviation Syndrome” is based upon the following criteria:<ref>{{Cite book | author = [[Human Rights Watch]] | title = Dangerous minds: political psychiatry in China today and its origins in the Mao era | year = 2002 | publisher = Human Rights Watch | location = [[New York, New York]] | isbn = 978-1-56432-278-4 | pages = }}</ref> * The subject being demonstrably normal before doing qigong exercises * Psychological and physiological reactions appearing during or after qigong exercises (suggestion and autosuggestion may play an important role in these reactions) * Complaints of abnormal sensations during or after qigong exercises * Diagnostic criteria do not meet other mental disorders such as [[schizophrenia]], [[affective disorder]], and [[neurosis]].
===Western psychiatry===
In [[East-West dichotomy|the West]], there was no equivalent experience until the adoption of qigong practices by the public became more common. When the Western medical community encountered abnormal conditions presenting in patients practicing qigong, they used the term "Qi-gong psychotic reaction" and classified the disorder as a [[culture-bound syndrome]] in the 4th edition of the ''[[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]]'' (DSM-IV) of the [[American Psychiatric Association]]. It is described as
''{{Quote|text=[a] term describing an acute, time-limited episode characterized by disassociative, paranoid, or other psychotic or non-psychotic symptoms that may occur after participation in the Chinese folk health-enhancing practice of qigong. Especially vulnerable are individuals who become overly involved in the practice.<ref>DSM-IV-TR, []American Psychiatric Association]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=w_HajjMnjxwC&pg=PA902 p. 902]</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Schatzberg | first1 = Alan F. | last2 = Hales | first2 = Robert E. | title = American Psychiatric Publishing Textbook of Psychiatry | publisher = American Psychiatric Publishing, Inc. | location = | isbn = 978-1-58562-257-3 | pages = 1551 | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=2RzFWRIAsPAC&pg=PA1551 | year = 2008 }} </ref><ref name=Vuong > {{Cite book |last =Vuong | first =Ngan Kim | chapter= Cultural Bound Syndromes: Qigong Psychotic Reaction |editor-last = Jackson | editor-first = Yo |title = Encyclopedia of Multicultural Psychology | year = 2006 | publisher = [[Sage Publications]] | location= | isbn = 978-1-4129-0948-8 | pages = 142–143 }} </ref><ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Sandhu | first1 = Daya Singh | title = Asian and Pacific Islander Americans : issues and concerns for counseling and psychotherapy | year = 1999 | publisher = [[Nova Science Publishers]] | location = [[Commack, New York]] | isbn = 978-1-56072-663-0 | pages = 231 | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=NfEt6s7i4RwC&pg=PA231#v=onepage&q&f=false }}</ref>}}''
In order to diagnose this disease in the West, practitioners determine the cultural formation of the patient; this includes their cultural reference group and how that culture might explain their illness.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hwang|first=Wei-Chin|title=Qi-gong Psychotic Reaction in a Chinese American Woman|journal=Culture, Medicine and Psychiatry|date=1 December 2007|volume=31|issue=4|pages=547–560|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11013-007-9065-z|accessdate=2013-05-14|doi=10.1007/s11013-007-9065-z}}</ref>
The [[DSM-IV codes|DSM-IV classification]] has been criticized by other Western psychiatrists on the grounds that
''{{Quote|text=[i]t is not clear how the architects of the DSM-IV can logically defend labeling a syndrome as aberrant in the context of a diagnostic system while simultaneously placing that syndrome outside of conventional Western [[nosologic]] categories that serve as basis for determining whether a syndrome is or is not aberrant and therefore a disorder.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Robinson | first1 = Bruce H. | title = Biomedicine: A Textbook for Practitioners of Acupuncture & Oriental Medicine | year = 2007 | publisher = Blue Poppy Press | location = | isbn = 978-1-891845-38-3 | page = 434 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=bL4X1HiasqEC&pg=PG434 }}</ref>}}''
==Medical causes==
The appearance of symptoms during or after qigong practice has been explained in various ways by the psychiatric community, in severe cases as an indication of latent [[psychosis]]. The Chinese medical literature includes a wider variety of symptoms associated with qigong deviation; the non-psychotic symptoms correspond to [[conversion disorder]] and [[histrionic personality disorder]] in Western classifications.<ref name=rob435/>
===Latent psychosis=== In cases of psychosis, a Western psychiatric belief is that qigong could be a precipitating stressor of a latent psychotic disorder to which the patient is predisposed, rather than erroneous qigong practice;<ref name=rob435>{{Cite book | last1 = Robinson | first1 = Bruce H. | title = Biomedicine: A Textbook for Practitioners of Acupuncture & Oriental Medicine | year = 2007 | publisher = Blue Poppy Press | location = | isbn = 978-1-891845-38-3 | page = 435 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=bL4X1HiasqEC&pg=PG435 }}</ref> a type of reactive psychosis or the precipitation of an underlying mental illness, such as [[schizophrenia]], [[bipolar disorder]], or [[posttraumatic stress disorder]].<ref>{{Cite journal |author=Sing, Lee, & Kleinman, Arthur | url=http://www.jaapl.org/cgi/reprint/30/1/120.pdf | title=Psychiatry in its Political and Professional Contexts: A Response to Robin Munro |journal=J Am Acad Psychiatry Law |volume=30:120–5 |year=2002 |page= 122}}</ref>
==Qigong community perspective==
Within the qigong community, Zou huo ru mo is believed to be caused by improper practice:<ref name=Xu>{{Cite book | last1 = Xu | first1 = Xiangcai | title = Qigong for Treating Common Ailments | year = 2000 | publisher = YMAA Publication Center | location = | isbn = 978-1-886969-70-4 | pages = }}</ref> * Inexperienced or unqualified instructor * Incorrect instructions * Impatience * Becoming frightened, irritated, confused, or suspicious during the course of qigong practice * Inappropriate focus, interpreted as "inappropriate channeling of qi (life energy)."
===Treatment=== Within the qigong community, there are specific treatments believed to be effective for addressing different forms of Zou huo ru mo.<ref name=Xu /> In particular, depending upon somatic versus psychological symptoms, and whether the condition is considered temporary or an intrinsic mental disorder, self-correction treatments can involve relaxation, walking, self-vibrating, self-patting, and self-massage. Clinical treatments can involve psychological counseling, expert guidance of practice, acupuncture, massage, "external qi" treatments, and symptomatic correction.<ref name=Liu2013CMQ>{{cite book|editor-last= Liu |editor-first=Tian Jun|editor-last2= Qiang |editor-first2=Xiao Mei | year=2013|title= Chinese Medical Qigong, Third Edition|publisher= Singing Dragon |isbn=978-1848190962}}</ref>{{rp|164–173}}
==Social and political context==
Qigong deviation became part of political controversy during the 1990s, when the [[Chinese government (disambiguation)|Chinese government]] became concerned about loss of state control due to [[Qigong fever|widespread popularity of qigong]], mass practice, and rise to power of charismatic qigong "grandmasters".<ref name = Nancy3 /><ref name=Ownby>{{cite book | last1 = Ownby | first1 = David | title = Falun Gong and the future of China | year = 2008 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | location = [[Oxford]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] | isbn = 978-0-19-532905-6 | pages = 181–186 }}</ref>
